children.text: Define central question
Select a social studies topic; ask questions to identify sub-topics
Formulate an essential question in the social studies
Formulate a thesis statement in the social studies that examines why as well as how
Search for relevant information
Identify key words; identify appropriate and varied sources; use basic search skills; use table of contents and indices as social studies reference materials
Identify key words, develop search strategies; locate appropriate and varied information sources; distinguish between primary and secondary sources
Identify key words; use advanced search strategies; independently locate appropriate and varied information sources; evaluate primary/secondary sources
Determine the source
Identify the time, place, audience, purpose, and form of a source
Evaluate information
Locate particular facts in social studies documents and identify the main idea
Recognize relevant facts and ideas in social studies documents; evaluate bias of sources/authors; classify information as fact/opinion
Evaluate reliability, credibility, and validity of information from a variety of social studies sources
Organize information
Locate data into graphic organizers
Take notes, paraphrase, summarize, enter data
Produce and interpret outlines, charts, graphs, maps, tables, timelines, and decision-making grids that explain problems and/or construct solutions
Apply information
Create a product that demonstrates understanding of information and responds to central questions; present product to a meaningful audience
Create a product that uses social studies content to support findings; present product in appropriate manner to a meaningful audience
Create a product that uses social studies content to support a thesis and present product in appropriate manner to a meaningful audience
Discussion skills
Communicate own feelings and beliefs; listen to viewpoints on social studies issues
Articulate a particular perspective/value orientation; demonstrate content knowledge; listen critically and build upon the ideas of others

Voice original ideas; demonstrate content knowledge; persuade audience; listen critically and build upon the ideas of others; ask clarifying questions and challenge statements of others; negotiate and compromise
Group interaction skills
Identify roles of different members of a group, serve in different roles in a group
Participate in delegating duties, establishing rules, planning, making decisions, taking action in group settings
Participate in developing group process, persuade, compromise, debate, resolve conflicts, and negotiate differences
Interview skills
Identify appropriate people to gain needed information, ask relevant questions, record answers
Identify appropriate people to gain needed information, ask relevant questions, pose follow-up questions; paraphrase conversations
Select appropriate people to gain needed information, identify bias of subject, ask questions to refine and verify understanding
Define and clarify a problem
Identify central issue; formulate appropriate questions
Identify central issue; formulate appropriate questions; identify multiple perspectives; compare and contrast; validate date using multiple sources; determine relevant information; paraphrase problem
Identify central issue; formulate appropriate questions; identify multiple perspectives; compare and contrast; validate data using multiple sources; determine relevant information; paraphrase problem
Judge information related to the problem
Distinguish between fact and opinion; clarify point of view; identify main message and target audience

Distinguish between fact, opinion, and reasoned argument; clarify time, point of view and purpose; recognize stereotypes, clichés, bias, and propaganda techniques; identify message and target audience of narrative and documents to determine credibility and authenticity

Distinguish between fact, opinion, and reasoned argument; clarify point of view and context; identify assumptions and fallacies, recognize stereotypes, clichés, bias, and propaganda techniques; evaluate accuracy and timeliness of information; determine main message and identify target audience; analyze credibility and authenticity
Solve problems and draw conclusions
Compare advantages and disadvantages, suggest solutions, decide appropriate course of action
Compare advantages and disadvantages, suggest alternate solutions; predict probable consequences, provide evidence to justify best solution
Compare benefits and costs, suggest logical alternatives, predict probable consequences, provide evidence to justify best solution, select most effective manner of communicating solution
Analyze cause and effect relationships
Investigate cause and effect relationships and their impact on people, environments, and economic systems
Analyze and evaluate the impact of ideas, events, and/or people on groups, environments, economic systems, and/or subsequent events
Hypothesize possible outcomes from an initial event recognizing multiple causes and accidental factors
Think chronologically
Group human and natural events into broadly defined eras and place in proper sequence on a timeline
Group human and natural events into broadly defined eras and construct related timelines
Group human and natural events into broadly defined eras and use timelines to explain patterns of continuity and change in the succession of events
Take perspective
Assume and portray others' points of view
Reconstruct and express others' points of view, highlighting a historic, geographic, civic, or economic perspective
Reconstruct and express multiple points of view and integrate a historic, geographic, civic, or economic perspective
